awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of a Machine Learning System to Identify Streptococcal Pharyngitis with a Smartphone Image
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact /commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses the lack of instant, remote medical tests for telehealth. This project could develop an accurate machine learning-based predictive model for strep throat. The business model delivers an artificial intelligence (AI)-based clinical decision support system as a Software as a Service subscription to urgent care telehealth services. The total addressable market for all telehealth point of care tests (beyond strep throat) in urgent care and primary care is $10.4 billion. This solution impacts antibiotic overprescribing and economics of health services. Currently, 34% of children and 75% of adults with pharyngitis receive unnecessary antibiotics, and this is 10-21% worse with telehealth. A remote point of care prediction for strep throat can potentially reduce the $22 million/year costs in unnecessary antibiotics and reduce drivers for drug-resistant bacteria. When pharyngitis is treated on telehealth it saves patients up to 1-3 hours per clinical visit and saves health insurance companies up to $100-400 per visit, compared to an emergency room or urgent care facility.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project advances the field of machine learning by combining smartphone image analysis and deep learning. These strategies are applied to a novel use case in digital health as remote screening for clinical decision support. The technical challenge is the development of a predictive model to achieve sensitivity and specificity acceptable for clinical adoption, at a target of > 80% (similar to the rapid antigen strep test). The strategy to meet this challenge is to increase the size of the dataset and experiment with multiple prediction models until goal performance is achieved. The project will also include designing an authentication system that validates sufficient images as recorded by an untrained patient and creating an intuitive user interface that enables consistent recordings by patients.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
During Phase I, CurieDx established the feasibility of StrepAI by developing an AI-driven clinical decision support mobile app and enabling a novel screening test for streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat) for telehealth. This project involved pioneering advancements inmachine learning by combining smartphone image analysis, multi-modal deep learning models, and human-centered design applied to a specific use case in digital health: remote screening for clinical decision support in identifying strep throat. The system’s technical challenges were met by creating a blended predictive model to achieve 96% area under the curve (AUC), on par with the rapid antigen strep test (93% AUC).

The StrepAI module overcame technical hurdles by ensuring the data used for training was robustand accurate. A training image database was developed and annotated with ground truth streptococcus test results. Machine learning techniques were applied to ensure images met quality standards for analysis using a machine learning model for object detection.A disease classification model was trained to detect image-based features consistent with strep throat, and produce adiagnostic prediction.

Using human factor design and iterative improvements in user interfaces, the intuitive workflowthrough the app was designed to allowed patients and caregivers to easily upload their images. The prototype of the StrepAI module was tested by end-user populations including patients and caregivers, clinicians, and health information technology leaders. Three cycles of qualitative user feedback from 5 users per round provided CurieDx insight to optimize the app’s user interface to guide successful image upload. This proprietary image authentication system validated that quality images are captured with greater than 95% success, which enhanced data reliability for machine learning model development, which ultimately laid the groundwork for its commercialization.

During Phase I funding, a mechanism to screen for the presence of a deep tissue abscess in the throat, or peritonsillar abscess, was developed. Resonant frequency changes in the voice are observed with peritonsillar abscesses. In this project, 4-5 word phrases were created that elicit the changes in formant frequencies classically heard in cases of peritonsillar abscess. A Delphi study was conducted to gather expert consensus from emergency physicians to reach agreement onwhich phrases elicit the vocal changes heard in a patient with peritonsillar abscess. There was 82.4% (SD 1.4%) agreement (defined as percent of responses that scored 7-9 on a Likert scale, ranging 1-9) among the physicians for 2 of the 4 phrases tested. This work identified unique phrases not previously described that can aid clinicians’ examination procedures to reliably identify high-risk diagnoses such as peritonsillar abscess.

For clinicians, the StrepAI prediction tool has commercial and clinical potential as a screening tool for telehealth, where medical tests are otherwise lacking. With this technology, clinicians can continue to practice the standard of care, with additional evidence-based clinical decision support toguide decision making. As this technology develops, there is opportunity to refine the human-machine collaboration to ensure trust and transparency of AI-assisted clinical decision support tools.

The project justified NSF support by addressing a significant healthcare challenge—convenient point of care testing for digital health delivery—using a scalable and sustainable approach. The StrepAI app is delivered as a Software as a Service (SaaS) subscription model for clinicians practicing telehealth and requires no extra hardware other than a smartphone with internet connectivity. The Phase I funding supported significant engineering breakthroughs to capture high-quality images, clinical data, and a refined strep throat disease classification tool to produce a valuable point of care screening test. These technological achievements were conducted through a partnership between academia (Johns Hopkins University) and industry (CurieDx). The individuals who contributed to this project were comprised of a majority of women or underrepresented minorities, and led to careers in STEM.  By leveraging StrepAI, the technology offers a cost-effective and efficient approach to improving diagnostic accuracy, reducing healthcare costs, and combating antibiotic resistance,aligning with NSF's mission to support transformative research with broad societal impacts.


Last Modified: 11/21/2024
Modified by: Therese Canares
